title: Fortune cookie
data:
**[English]()** • [中文（中国大陆）‎](/wiki/Fortune_cookie/zh-CN "Fortune cookie/zh-CN")

| % [![Fortune cookie.png](/images/2/24/Fortune_cookie.png)](/wiki/File:Fortune_cookie.png) |                                                        |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------ |
| Name                                                                                      | fortune cookie                                         |
| Base price                                                                                | 7 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")                        |
| Nutrition                                                                                 | [40](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition")                      |
| Turns to eat                                                                              | 1                                                      |
| Weight                                                                                    | [1](/wiki/Weight "Weight")                             |
| Conduct                                                                                   | [vegetarian (literate)](/wiki/Conduct#Vegan "Conduct") |

A **fortune cookie** is a type of [comestible](/wiki/Comestible "Comestible") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is [veggy](/wiki/Veggy "Veggy") and considered [vegetarian](/wiki/Vegetarian "Vegetarian").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Messages](#Messages)

- [7 Variants](#Variants)

  - [7.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [7.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [7.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [7.4 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Fortune cookies make up 5.5% of all randomly-generated comestibles.

All [Monks](/wiki/Monk "Monk") start with 3 to 6 fortune cookies.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) [Tourists](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") can start with food rations among their initial stacks of food.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

General [stores](/wiki/Store "Store"), delicatessens and health food stores can sell fortune cookies.

[Applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a [charged](/wiki/Charged "Charged") [horn of plenty](/wiki/Horn_of_plenty "Horn of plenty") has a 51⁄1000 chance (5.1%) of generating a fortune cookie or two.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

## Description

When [eaten](/wiki/Eaten "Eaten"), a fortune cookie provides 40 [nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition") and leaves behind a fortune that is automatically [read](/wiki/Read "Read") unless the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") is [blind](/wiki/Blind "Blind"). The fortune is a [rumor](/wiki/Rumor "Rumor") whose veracity depends on the cookie's [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude"): Blessed fortune cookies always contain true rumors, cursed fortune cookies always contain false rumors, and uncursed fortune cookies may contain either with equal probability. Fortune cookies will never be [rotten](/wiki/Rotten "Rotten") when eaten regardless of their beatitude.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

Characters can read fortune cookies manually, breaking the cookie and throwing away the pieces before reading the fortune inside. Reading the fortune through either method breaks [illiterate](/wiki/Illiterate "Illiterate") conduct.

[Thrown](/wiki/Thrown "Thrown") fortune cookies can be used to [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame") [domestic](/wiki/Domestic "Domestic") [canines](/wiki/Canine "Canine") and [felines](/wiki/Feline "Feline"), despite being veggy.

## Strategy

Fortune cookies are a lightweight means of taming domestic carnivores, and otherwise make a quick snack for non-vegan characters. Other characters can preserve vegan or [foodless](/wiki/Foodless "Foodless") conduct by reading the cookie instead of eating it, while illiterate conduct can be preserved by using it solely to tame pets as above - if a fortune cookie must be eaten, the character can [blind](/wiki/Blind "Blind") themselves before eating it.

## History

The fortune cookie first appears in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Fortune cookie](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/Fortune_cookie "wikipedia:Special:Search/Fortune cookie")***

A fortune cookie is a crisp and sugary cookie wafer made from flour, sugar, vanilla, and sesame seed oil, and usually contains a piece of paper with a "fortune", an aphorism or a vague prophecy. The message inside may also include a Chinese phrase with translation and/or a list of lucky numbers used by some as lottery numbers. Fortune cookies are often served as a dessert in Chinese restaurants in the United States, Canada, Australia, and other countries; there is also a Japanese variant that lacks the Chinese lucky numbers and were eaten with tea.

Despite the association with Chinese restaurants, they are not Chinese in origin - the exact origin of fortune cookies is unclear, with various immigrant groups in California claiming to have popularized them in the early 20th century; a comment in the code of *NetHack* attributes them to George Jung in Los Angeles, California in 1916.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) David Jung, founder of the Hong Kong Noodle Company in Los Angeles, claims that he invented the cookie in 1918, while Seiichi Kito, the founder of Fugetsu-do of Little Tokyo in Los Angeles, also claims to have invented the cookie by getting the idea from *Omikuji* (fortune slip) sold at temples and shrines in Japan.

## Messages

- This fortune cookie is \<delicious/terrible!>

  You ate a fortune cookie, with "terrible" used for cursed cookies.

- You break up the cookie and throw away the pieces.

  You "read" a fortune cookie.

- This cookie has a scrap of paper inside. It reads:

  You read the fortune inside the cookie.

- What a pity you cannot read it!

  This replaces the second sentence if you read or eat the cookie while blind.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), fortune cookies give a "yes/no" prompt for their fortune when eaten, which allows characters to more easily maintain illiterate conduct. This also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

### UnNetHack

[UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") incorporates the Free Fortune Cookie Patch, which gives szechuan [tins](/wiki/Tin "Tin") a 1⁄2 chance of containing a free fortune cookie. It also incorporates the [Advent calendar](/wiki/Advent_calendar "Advent calendar") patch, which has a significant chance of generating a fortune cookie as the "prize" in each of the 23 small rooms prior to Christmas Eve.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), draugr Monks have their fortune cookies replaced with [eggs](/wiki/Egg "Egg").

### Hack'EM

[Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM") also incorporates the Free Fortune Cookie Patch, which gives szechuan tins a 1⁄2 chance of containing a free fortune cookie.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"Check if it incorporates the prompt from SLASH'EM"*

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 97](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L97)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 144](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L144)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2219](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkobj.c#L2219): *any comestible that can be randomly generated is eligible*
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2674](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/eat.c#L2674)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 94](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L94)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Fortune cookie

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
English

 • 中文（中国大陆）‎
%
Name fortune cookie
Base price 7 zm
Nutrition 40
Turns to eat 1
Weight 1
Conduct vegetarian (literate)

A fortune cookie is a type of comestible that appears in NetHack. It is veggy and considered vegetarian.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Origin
  • 6 Messages
  • 7 Variants
    • 7.1 SLASH'EM
    • 7.2 UnNetHack
    • 7.3 EvilHack
    • 7.4 Hack'EM
  • 8 References

Generation

Fortune cookies make up 5.5% of all randomly-generated comestibles.

All Monks start with 3 to 6 fortune cookies.[1] Tourists can start with food rations among their initial stacks of food.[2]

General stores, delicatessens and health food stores can sell fortune cookies.

Applying a charged horn of plenty has a 51⁄1000 chance (5.1%) of generating a fortune cookie or two.[3]

Description

When eaten, a fortune cookie provides 40 nutrition and leaves behind a fortune that is automatically read unless the hero is blind. The fortune is a rumor whose veracity depends on the cookie's beatitude: Blessed fortune cookies always contain true rumors, cursed fortune cookies always contain false rumors, and uncursed fortune cookies may contain either with equal probability. Fortune cookies will never be rotten when eaten regardless of their beatitude.[4]

Characters can read fortune cookies manually, breaking the cookie and throwing away the pieces before reading the fortune inside. Reading the fortune through either method breaks illiterate conduct.

Thrown fortune cookies can be used to tame domestic canines and felines, despite being veggy.

Strategy

Fortune cookies are a lightweight means of taming domestic carnivores, and otherwise make a quick snack for non-vegan characters. Other characters can preserve vegan or foodless conduct by reading the cookie instead of eating it, while illiterate conduct can be preserved by using it solely to tame pets as above - if a fortune cookie must be eaten, the character can blind themselves before eating it.

History

The fortune cookie first appears in Hack 1.0.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Fortune cookie

A fortune cookie is a crisp and sugary cookie wafer made from flour, sugar, vanilla, and sesame seed oil, and usually contains a piece of paper with a "fortune", an aphorism or a vague prophecy. The message inside may also include a Chinese phrase with translation and/or a list of lucky numbers used by some as lottery numbers. Fortune cookies are often served as a dessert in Chinese restaurants in the United States, Canada, Australia, and other countries; there is also a Japanese variant that lacks the Chinese lucky numbers and were eaten with tea.

Despite the association with Chinese restaurants, they are not Chinese in origin - the exact origin of fortune cookies is unclear, with various immigrant groups in California claiming to have popularized them in the early 20th century; a comment in the code of NetHack attributes them to George Jung in Los Angeles, California in 1916.[5] David Jung, founder of the Hong Kong Noodle Company in Los Angeles, claims that he invented the cookie in 1918, while Seiichi Kito, the founder of Fugetsu-do of Little Tokyo in Los Angeles, also claims to have invented the cookie by getting the idea from Omikuji (fortune slip) sold at temples and shrines in Japan.

Messages

This fortune cookie is <delicious/terrible!>
You ate a fortune cookie, with "terrible" used for cursed cookies.
You break up the cookie and throw away the pieces.
You "read" a fortune cookie.
This cookie has a scrap of paper inside. It reads:
You read the fortune inside the cookie.
What a pity you cannot read it!
This replaces the second sentence if you read or eat the cookie while blind.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, fortune cookies give a "yes/no" prompt for their fortune when eaten, which allows characters to more easily maintain illiterate conduct. This also applies to SlashTHEM.

UnNetHack

UnNetHack incorporates the Free Fortune Cookie Patch, which gives szechuan tins a 1⁄2 chance of containing a free fortune cookie. It also incorporates the Advent calendar patch, which has a significant chance of generating a fortune cookie as the "prize" in each of the 23 small rooms prior to Christmas Eve.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, draugr Monks have their fortune cookies replaced with eggs.

Hack'EM

Hack'EM also incorporates the Free Fortune Cookie Patch, which gives szechuan tins a 1⁄2 chance of containing a free fortune cookie.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

"Check if it incorporates the prompt from SLASH'EM"

References

  1. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 97
  2. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 144
  3. ↑ src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2219: any comestible that can be randomly generated is eligible
  4. ↑ src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2674
  5. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 94

A '''fortune cookie''' is a type of [[comestible]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is [[veggy]] and considered [[vegetarian]].

==Generation==
Fortune cookies make up 5.5% of all randomly-generated comestibles.

All [[Monk]]s start with 3 to 6 fortune cookies.{{refsrc|src/u_init.c|97|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} [[Tourist]]s can start with food rations among their initial stacks of food.{{refsrc|src/u_init.c|144|version=NetHack 3.6.7|Initial inventory for Tourists}}

General [[store]]s, delicatessens and health food stores can sell fortune cookies.

[[Apply]]ing a [[charged]] [[horn of plenty]] has a {{frac|51|1000}} chance (5.1%) of generating a fortune cookie or two.{{refsrc|src/mkobj.c|2219|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=any comestible that can be randomly generated is eligible}}

==Description==
When [[eaten]], a fortune cookie provides 40 [[nutrition]] and leaves behind a fortune that is automatically [[read]] unless the [[hero]] is [[blind]]. The fortune is a [[rumor]] whose veracity depends on the cookie's [[beatitude]]: Blessed fortune cookies always contain true rumors, cursed fortune cookies always contain false rumors, and uncursed fortune cookies may contain either with equal probability. Fortune cookies will never be [[rotten]] when eaten regardless of their beatitude.{{refsrc|src/eat.c|2674|nethack=3.6.7}}

Characters can read fortune cookies manually, breaking the cookie and throwing away the pieces before reading the fortune inside. Reading the fortune through either method breaks [[illiterate]] conduct.

[[Thrown]] fortune cookies can be used to [[tame]] [[domestic]] [[canine]]s and [[feline]]s, despite being veggy.

==Strategy==
Fortune cookies are a lightweight means of taming domestic carnivores, and otherwise make a quick snack for non-vegan characters. Other characters can preserve vegan or [[foodless]] conduct by reading the cookie instead of eating it, while illiterate conduct can be preserved by using it solely to tame pets as above - if a fortune cookie must be eaten, the character can [[blind]] themselves before eating it.

==History==
The fortune cookie first appears in [[Hack 1.0]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia}}
A fortune cookie is a crisp and sugary cookie wafer made from flour, sugar, vanilla, and sesame seed oil, and usually contains a piece of paper with a "fortune", an aphorism or a vague prophecy. The message inside may also include a Chinese phrase with translation and/or a list of lucky numbers used by some as lottery numbers. Fortune cookies are often served as a dessert in Chinese restaurants in the United States, Canada, Australia, and other countries; there is also a Japanese variant that lacks the Chinese lucky numbers and were eaten with tea.

Despite the association with Chinese restaurants, they are not Chinese in origin - the exact origin of fortune cookies is unclear, with various immigrant groups in California claiming to have popularized them in the early 20th century; a comment in the code of ''NetHack'' attributes them to George Jung in Los Angeles, California in 1916.{{refsrc|src/u_init.c|94|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} David Jung, founder of the Hong Kong Noodle Company in Los Angeles, claims that he invented the cookie in 1918, while Seiichi Kito, the founder of Fugetsu-do of Little Tokyo in Los Angeles, also claims to have invented the cookie by getting the idea from ''Omikuji'' (fortune slip) sold at temples and shrines in Japan.

==Messages==
{{message|This fortune cookie is <delicious/terrible!>|You ate a fortune cookie, with "terrible" used for cursed cookies.}}
{{message|You break up the cookie and throw away the pieces.|You "read" a fortune cookie.}}
{{message|This cookie has a scrap of paper inside. It reads:|You read the fortune inside the cookie.}}
{{message|What a pity you cannot read it!|This replaces the second sentence if you read or eat the cookie while blind.}}

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], fortune cookies give a "yes/no" prompt for their fortune when eaten, which allows characters to more easily maintain illiterate conduct. This also applies to [[SlashTHEM]].

===UnNetHack===
[[UnNetHack]] incorporates the Free Fortune Cookie Patch, which gives szechuan [[tin]]s a {{frac|2}} chance of containing a free fortune cookie. It also incorporates the [[Advent calendar]] patch, which has a significant chance of generating a fortune cookie as the "prize" in each of the 23 small rooms prior to Christmas Eve.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], draugr Monks have their fortune cookies replaced with [[egg]]s.

===Hack'EM===
[[Hack'EM]] also incorporates the Free Fortune Cookie Patch, which gives szechuan tins a {{frac|2}} chance of containing a free fortune cookie.
